meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: An Ordinance to ensure the safety and health of persons when they are at work, to provide for related matters, and to consequentially amend the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance and the Administrative Appeals Board Ordinance.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Occupational Safety and Health Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Purposes of Ordinance
section.leadIn: The purposes of this Ordinance are as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to ensure the safety and health of employees when they are at work;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to prescribe measures that will contribute to making the workplaces of employees safer and healthier for them;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to improve the safety and health standards applicable to certain hazardous processes, plant and substances used or kept in workplaces;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: generally to improve the safety and health aspects of working environments of employees.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: activity (活動) includes operation and process;
Appeal Board (上訴委員會) means the Administrative Appeals Board established under section 5 of the Administrative Appeals Board Ordinance (Cap. 442);
Commissioner (處長) means the Commissioner for Labour;
court (法庭) includes a magistrate;
dangerous occurrence (危險事故) means an occurrence of a kind specified in Schedule 1;
domestic premises (住宅處所) means premises occupied as a private dwelling;
domestic servant (家庭傭工) has the same meaning as in the Employment Ordinance (Cap. 57);
employee (僱員) means a natural person who works under a contract of employment or apprenticeship, but does not include a domestic servant;
employer (僱主) means a person who employs natural persons under contracts of employment or apprenticeship;
function (職能) includes a power and a duty;
identity card (身分證) means an identity card issued under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177);
improvement notice (敦促改善通知書) means a notice served under section 9;
occupational safety officer (職業安全主任) means a public officer designated as such under section 20 or a person taken to be so designated because of that section;

occupier (佔用人), in relation to any premises or workplace, includes a person who has any degree of control over the premises or workplace and, in particular, includes a person to whom subsection (5) or (6) applies;

def.name: OffenceOfStrictLiability
def.leadIn: offence of strict liability (嚴格法律責任罪行) means an offence in relation to the prosecution of which it is not necessary for the prosecutor to prove—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the defendant did the act or omission constituting the offence intentionally, knowingly or recklessly; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the defendant had knowledge of any specific ingredient of the offence;

subsection.def: person responsible (負責人), in relation to a workplace, has the meaning given by subsection (2);

public analyst (公職分析員) means the Government Chemist, the Government Pathologist or any analyst appointed in writing by the Chief Executive for the purposes of this Ordinance; (Amended 54 of 2000 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any public street, pier or public garden; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the permanent way of a railway; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any part of the territorial sea or any publicly navigable waterway; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any part of the airspace above Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any other place to which people are entitled to have access whether with or without payment;

subsection.def: serious bodily injury (嚴重身體傷害), in relation to a person, includes any bodily injury that results in the person’s admission at a hospital or clinic for treatment or observation;
suspension notice (暫時停工通知書) means a notice served under section 10;
vessel (船隻) has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Shipping and Port Control Ordinance (Cap. 313);
work (工作) means work as an employee;

def.name: Workplace
def.leadIn: workplace (工作地點) means any place where employees work, but does not include any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an aircraft or vessel when located in a public place;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: domestic premises at which the only employees are domestic servants;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a place at which only self-employed persons work;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any other place of a kind prescribed by a regulation for the purposes of this paragraph;

subsection.def: workplace code of practice (工作地點工作守則) means a code of practice issued under section 40(1) and, if such a code has been amended, means the code as amended.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Ordinance, the person responsible for a workplace is the employer of the employees who are employed to carry out work there, or if the employer does not exercise any degree of control over the relevant part or aspect of the workplace, means the occupier of the workplace.

For the purposes of this Ordinance, risks arising out of the activities of persons at work are taken to include risks attributable to the manner of conducting an undertaking, risks attributable to the plant or substances used in connection with an undertaking and risks attributable to the condition of premises so used.

For the purposes of this Ordinance, a person is at work only during the time when the person is actually at a workplace. However, a person is not to be regarded as being at work at a workplace for those purposes when the person is being conveyed as a passenger in a vehicle referred to in paragraph (b) of the definition of workplace in circumstances no different from those applicable to persons being so conveyed who are not at work at a workplace.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, under a lease or contract, has an obligation for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the maintenance or repair of premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the safety of, or the absence of risks to health arising from the condition or use of, any plant or substance located on premises,

subsection.continued: is taken to be an occupier of the premises for the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: A person who, under a lease or contract, has an obligation to provide, maintain or repair a means of access to, or egress from, premises is taken to be an occupier of the premises for the purposes of this Ordinance.
Subsections (5) and (6) do not apply to persons in their capacity as occupiers of domestic premises.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Application of Ordinance to certain persons
section.content: This Ordinance applies to independent contractors and self-employed persons only in their capacity as employers or as occupiers of premises where workplaces are located.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Ordinance to bind Government

subsection.content: This Ordinance binds the Government.
Neither the Government nor any public officer in the officer’s capacity as such is liable to be prosecuted for an offence against this Ordinance.

part.name: P2
part.heading: Responsibility for Safety and Health of Employees at Work

section.name: s6
section.heading: Employers to ensure safety and health of employees

subsection.content: Every employer must, so far as reasonably practicable, ensure the safety and health at work of all the employer’s employees.

subsection.leadIn: The cases in which an employer fails to comply with subsection (1) include (but are not limited to) the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a failure to provide or maintain plant and systems of work that are, so far as reasonably practicable, safe and without risks to health;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a failure to make arrangements for ensuring, so far as reasonably practicable, safety and absence of risks to health in connection with the use, handling, storage or transport of plant or substances;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a failure to provide such information, instruction, training and supervision as may be necessary to ensure, so far as reasonably practicable, the safety and health at work of the employer’s employees;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: as regards any workplace under the employer’s control—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a failure to maintain the workplace in a condition that is, so far as reasonably practicable, safe and without risks to health; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a failure to provide or maintain means of access to and egress from the workplace that are, so far as reasonably practicable, safe and without any such risks;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a failure to provide or maintain a working environment for the employer’s employees that is, so far as reasonably practicable, safe and without risks to health.

subsection.leadIn: An employer who fails to comply with subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable— (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 65)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine of $3,000,000; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $10,000,000. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 65)

subsection.leadIn: An employer who fails to comply with subsection (1) intentionally, knowingly or recklessly commits an offence and is liable— (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 65)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine of $3,000,000 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $10,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 65)

section.name: s7
section.heading: Occupier of premises to ensure safety and health of persons employed at those premises

subsection.leadIn: If an employee’s workplace is located on premises that are not under the control of the employee’s employer, the occupier of the premises must ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the means of access to and egress from the premises; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any plant or substances kept at the premises,

subsection.continued: are, so far as reasonably practicable, safe and without risks to health.

subsection.leadIn: An occupier who fails to comply with subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable— (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 66)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine of $3,000,000; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $10,000,000.

subsection.content: An occupier who fails to comply with subsection (1) intentionally, knowingly or recklessly commits an offence and is liable— (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 66)(a)on summary conviction—to a fine of $3,000,000 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or(b)on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $10,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Employees at work to take care of others and to co-operate with employer

subsection.leadIn: An employee while at work—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must, so far as reasonably practicable, take care for the safety and health of persons (including the employee) who are at the employee’s workplace and who may be affected by the employee’s acts or omissions at work; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as regards any requirement imposed in the interests of safety or health on the employee’s employer or any other person by this or any other Ordinance, must, so far as reasonably practicable, co-operate with the employer or other person so far as may be necessary to enable the requirement to be complied with.

subsection.content: An employee who fails to comply with subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $150,000.
An employee who fails to comply with subsection (1) intentionally, knowingly or recklessly commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Commissioner may serve improvement notice on employer or occupier

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may serve an improvement notice on an employer, or an occupier of premises where a workplace is located, if of the opinion that the employer or occupier—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is contravening this Ordinance or the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has contravened either of those Ordinances in circumstances that make it likely that the contravention will be continued or repeated.

subsection.leadIn: An improvement notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identify the employer or occupier concerned; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: state that the Commissioner is of the opinion that the employer or occupier is contravening this Ordinance or the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59), or has contravened either of those Ordinances in circumstances referred to in subsection (1)(b); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: specify the provision of this Ordinance or the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59) in relation to which the Commissioner has formed that opinion; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: require the employer or occupier either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to remedy the contravention within a period specified in the notice; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to refrain from continuing or repeating the contravention.

subsection.content: The period specified in subsection (2)(e)(i) must be a reasonable one having regard to the requirement imposed on the employer or occupier concerned.
The Commissioner may, by notice in writing served on the employer or occupier concerned, amend or revoke an improvement notice or suspend its operation.

An employer or occupier who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement of an improvement notice commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $400,000 and to imprisonment for 12 months. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 68)

In proceedings for an offence against subsection (5), the defendant has a reasonable excuse for not complying with a requirement of an improvement notice if the defendant establishes that it was not reasonably practicable to comply with the requirement.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Commissioner may serve suspension notice on employer or occupier

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may serve a suspension notice on an employer who is responsible for, or on an occupier of, premises where a workplace is located, if of the opinion that because of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an activity undertaken on the premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the condition or use of the premises or of any plant or substance located on the premises,

subsection.continued: there is an imminent risk of death or serious bodily injury.

subsection.leadIn: A suspension notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identify the employer or occupier concerned; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the matters that, in the Commissioner’s opinion, create, or are likely to create, a risk of death or serious bodily injury; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: direct the activity not to be undertaken, or the premises, plant or substance not to be used, while the notice remains in force.

subsection.content: A suspension notice takes effect on the date on which it is served, or on such later date as is specified in the notice, and, except when its operation is suspended, remains in force until it is revoked.

subsection.leadIn: Where a suspension notice is in force in relation to an activity, premises, plant or a substance, the Commissioner must, by notice in writing served on the employer or occupier concerned, revoke the suspension notice on being satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the undertaking of the activity on the premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the condition or use of the premises, or of any plant or substance located on the premises,

subsection.continued: no longer creates, and is no longer likely to create, an imminent risk of death or serious bodily injury.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may, by notice in writing served on the employer or occupier concerned, amend a suspension notice or suspend its operation.

subsection.leadIn: An employer or occupier who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes a suspension notice commits an offence and is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 12 months; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a further fine of $100,000 for each day or part of a day during which the offender knowingly and intentionally continues the contravention. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 69)

section.name: s11
section.heading: Right of employer or occupier to have suspension notice reviewed

subsection.content: Within 28 days after being served with a suspension notice, the employer or occupier concerned may make an application in writing to the Commissioner for a review of the notice.

subsection.leadIn: An application must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the grounds on which it is based.

subsection.content: Within 14 days after receiving an application for the review of a suspension notice, the Commissioner must determine the application either by confirming the notice or by revoking or varying it.

As soon as practicable after determining an application for the review of a suspension notice, the Commissioner must, by written notice, inform the applicant of the decision. If the suspension notice is not revoked as a result of the review, the decision must contain a statement of the reasons for the decision.
A suspension notice is taken to be revoked if the Commissioner fails to determine an application for its review within 14 days after receiving the application.
Subject to subsection (5), the operation of a suspension notice is not affected by the making of an application under this section or the lodgement of an appeal under section 12.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Employer or occupier may appeal to Appeal Board against Commissioner’s decision

subsection.content: An employer or occupier affected by a decision of the Commissioner under section 11 may appeal to the Appeal Board against the decision.
An appeal must be lodged with the Appeal Board within 28 days after the decision is notified in writing to the employer or occupier concerned.

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of an appeal under this section relating to a suspension notice, the Appeal Board may do one of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: revoke the notice on the grounds that the circumstances that gave rise to the service of the notice have ceased to exist or that the directions contained in the notice are unreasonable;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if satisfied that the circumstances that gave rise to the service of the notice continue to exist, modify the notice on the ground that the directions contained in the notice are unreasonable;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: refuse the appeal on the grounds that the circumstances that gave rise to the service of the notice continue to exist and that the directions contained in the notice are reasonable.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Person responsible for workplace to notify accidents and other matters

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an accident occurs at a workplace; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the accident causes the death of, or serious bodily injury to, an employee,

subsection.continued: the person responsible for the workplace must notify the accident to an occupational safety officer within 24 hours after the time when the accident occurred.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notification of an accident under subsection (1) is not contained in a written report that contains the particulars required by subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an employee who is a victim of an accident that has occurred at a workplace (other than an accident notified under subsection (1)) has been incapacitated by the accident,

subsection.continued: the person responsible for the workplace must in writing report the accident to an occupational safety officer within 7 days after the date of the accident.

subsection.leadIn: A report prepared for the purposes of subsection (2) must contain the following particulars—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name and principal business address of the occupier of the premises concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the victim is an employee of an employer who is not the occupier of the premises, the name and principal business address of the employer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the name, residential address, gender, identity card number, age (if known) and occupation (if any) of the victim of the accident;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: details of the industrial, commercial or other activities carried on at the workplace;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: particulars of the accident, including the injury and whether death or incapacity ensued and the activity that the victim was engaged in at the time of the accident.

subsection.content: A report of an accident is not required under subsection (3) if notice of the accident has been given in accordance with section 15 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282).

If a victim of an accident that occurred at a workplace dies after the accident has been notified or reported in accordance with this section, the person responsible for the workplace must, within 24 hours after becoming aware of the death, report the death to an occupational safety officer and to the police officer in charge of the police station nearest to the workplace. The report can be made orally or in writing.
A person responsible for a workplace who fails to comply with a requirement of this section commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 70)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: incapacitated (喪失工作能力), in relation to a victim of an accident, means that the victim is permanently or temporarily incapacitated from working in any capacity in which, but for the accident, the victim would have been capable of working.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this section, a victim of an accident is incapacitated from working only if the incapacity prevents the victim from working for at least 3 days.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Occupier of relevant premises to report dangerous occurrence to occupational safety officer

subsection.content: The occupier of premises where a workplace is located must report to an occupational safety officer any dangerous occurrence that occurs at the workplace.
The report must be in writing and be lodged within 24 hours after the dangerous occurrence concerned.

subsection.leadIn: The report must contain the following particulars—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time of the occurrence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: particulars of damage to, or the destruction of, property;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the circumstances of the occurrence.

subsection.content: This section must be complied with even though the occurrence has been notified or reported in accordance with section 13.
An occupier of premises who fails to comply with a requirement of this section commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 71)

section.name: s15
section.heading: Medical practitioner to notify occupational disease to Commissioner

subsection.leadIn: If, on examining an employee or a former employee or the body of a person who was immediately before the death an employee or former employee, a medical practitioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: finds or suspects that the employee or former employee is or was suffering from an occupational disease specified in Schedule 2; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: believes that the disease was or may have been attributable to an occupation specified in column 3 of that Schedule,

subsection.continued: the practitioner must notify the finding or suspicion to the Commissioner.

subsection.content: The notification must be in writing and on a form provided or approved by the Commissioner and must be lodged as soon as practicable after the conclusion is formed.
A medical practitioner who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with this section commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 72)

section.name: s16
section.heading: Holding of informal inquiry into workplace accident or dangerous occurrence

subsection.content: Whenever an accident or dangerous occurrence occurs in a workplace, the Commissioner may arrange for an inquiry to be held to determine the causes of the accident or occurrence and the circumstances in which it occurred.
An occupational safety officer designated by the Commissioner is to conduct the inquiry.

The occupational safety officer designated to conduct an inquiry is required to conduct the inquiry in an informal manner and to report the findings of the inquiry to the Commissioner. The report must be in writing.

subsection.leadIn: The occupational safety officer conducting an inquiry may terminate the inquiry if, in the course of the inquiry, that officer considers that it is not possible to conclude the inquiry—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: because a person who appears to that officer to have relevant information or relevant documents is unable or unwilling—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to provide the information; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to produce the documents; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: to answer questions about any relevant matter; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for any other reason.

subsection.content: On terminating an inquiry under subsection (4), the occupational safety officer concerned must notify the termination to the Commissioner. The notice must be in writing and must state the reasons for the termination.
This section applies to an accident or dangerous occurrence whether or not it involves the death of, or bodily injury to, a person.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Holding of formal inquiry into workplace accident or dangerous occurrence

subsection.content: On receiving a termination notice under section 16, the Commissioner may arrange for an inquiry to be held into the causes of the accident or dangerous occurrence and the circumstances in which it occurred.
The Commissioner may conduct the inquiry personally or designate a deputy commissioner for labour to conduct it.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner or the deputy commissioner for labour conducting the inquiry may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: examine witnesses and parties on oath; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by notice in writing, direct the attendance at the inquiry of witnesses in order to give evidence or to produce documents or other material evidence.

subsection.content: A person cannot be required to produce at an inquiry any document or other material evidence that the person could not be required to produce in civil proceedings before a court.

The Commissioner or the deputy commissioner for labour conducting an inquiry is not bound by the rules of evidence and can receive any evidence that appears to be relevant to determining the matters being inquired into.

subsection.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse, fails to attend to give evidence or produce documents or other material evidence at an inquiry after being required to do so; or

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: refuses to answer a question put to the person or to produce a document or other material evidence that is in the possession or under the control of the person; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in answer to a question put to the person, provides information that is to the person’s knowledge false or misleading; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: produces a document or other material evidence that is to the person’s knowledge false or misleading,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 73)

subsection.content: A person to whom a question is put at an inquiry is not excused from answering the question on the ground that the answer might tend to incriminate the person.

subsection.leadIn: However, neither the question nor the answer is admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings (other than proceedings charging the person with having committed in relation to the answer perjury under section 31 of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200) or an offence under subsection (6)(b)(ii))—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person claims before answering the question that the answer might tend to incriminate the person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person’s entitlement to make such a claim was not brought to the person’s attention before the question was answered.

subsection.content: A person giving evidence or producing a document or other material evidence at an inquiry is, subject to subsection (7), entitled to the same privileges and immunities as a witness in civil proceedings before the Court of First Instance. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

A person who, at an inquiry, behaves in an insulting or threatening manner towards another person, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 3 months. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 73)

section.name: s18
section.heading: Coronial inquest not affected by inquiry under section 17
section.content: The holding of an inquiry under section 17 does not affect the holding of an inquiry under the Coroners Ordinance (Cap. 14).

section.name: s19
section.heading: Appointment of officers to administer Ordinance

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may appoint a Commissioner for Labour and such other officers as the Chief Executive considers necessary for the administration and enforcement of this Ordinance and the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59). (Amended 54 of 2000 s. 3)

Persons holding office under section 3 of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59) immediately before the commencement of this section are taken to be appointed under subsection (1) on the same terms and with the same entitlements as those applicable to those persons immediately before that commencement.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Commissioner may assign designations to officers

subsection.content: The Commissioner may designate as occupational safety officers any of the officers appointed or taken to be appointed under section 19.
The Commissioner may also assign ranks to those officers and designations and ranks to other officers so appointed or taken to be so appointed.
The Commissioner is, by virtue of holding office as such, an occupational safety officer.

Persons who are taken to be appointed under section 19 and who, immediately before the commencement of this section, were inspectors within the meaning of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59) are taken to be occupational safety officers.

subsection.leadIn: The following persons are also occupational safety officers—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every health officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other public officer authorized in writing by the Commissioner, either generally or specially for a specific purpose or occasion, to exercise and perform the functions of an occupational safety officer.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Exercise or performance of functions by occupational safety officers

subsection.content: The Commissioner is required to issue a certificate of authority to each occupational safety officer (other than the Commissioner or a health officer).

subsection.leadIn: A certificate of authority must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state that it is issued under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give the name of the person to whom it is issued; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: describe the nature of the functions conferred or imposed on the person; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: state that it is issued with the Commissioner’s authority.

subsection.leadIn: When exercising or performing a function under this Ordinance or any other Ordinance, an occupational safety officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be accompanied and assisted by such persons as the officer reasonably requires in order to exercise or perform the function; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must, if required to do so, produce for inspection the officer’s certificate of authority.

subsection.content: Subsection (3)(b) does not apply to the Commissioner or a health officer, but, when exercising or performing a function of an occupational safety officer, the Commissioner or a health officer must, if required to do so, produce for inspection evidence of his or her appointment as such.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Power to enter premises where workplace is located

subsection.leadIn: An occupational safety officer may, without warrant, enter and inspect premises if the officer believes on reasonable grounds that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the premises are being used as a workplace; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a contravention of this Ordinance is being or has been committed on the premises.

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may, on the application of the Commissioner, issue a warrant authorizing an occupational safety officer to enter premises with such force as may be necessary if the magistrate is satisfied, on sworn information—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an occupational safety officer has sought admission to those premises but admission has been refused; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: refusal of admission to the premises is reasonably expected; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the premises are unoccupied; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the case is one of urgency; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there is a good reason for an occupational safety officer to enter the premises.

subsection.content: On leaving unoccupied premises entered in accordance with this section, an occupational safety officer must ensure that they are as effectively secured against trespassers as the officer found them at the time of entry.
A warrant issued under this section continues in force for 1 month or until the purpose for which entry is required has been fulfilled, whichever first occurs.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Powers of occupational safety officers who have entered premises

subsection.leadIn: An occupational safety officer who has entered premises under section 22 may do all or any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: seize any article that the officer reasonably believes to be evidence of a contravention of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: conduct tests or examinations of any plant or substance found on the premises;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: conduct tests to determine the atmospheric or other physical condition of the environment of the premises;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the officer reasonably believes that any substance found on the premises could prejudice the safety or health of employees who work on the premises, take samples of the substance for analysis;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: take photographs of the premises or of any plant or substance found on the premises;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: if the officer is a medical practitioner, carry out a medical examination of a person (but only with the person’s consent);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: require the occupier of the premises or any person who is apparently an employee or agent of that occupier to provide the officer with such assistance and facilities as is or are reasonably necessary to enable the officer to exercise or perform the officer’s functions;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: require any person found on the premises to produce for inspection the person’s identity card if the officer reasonably suspects that the person has committed an offence against this Ordinance or is able to provide evidence of the commission of such an offence;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: require any person on the premises to produce for inspection records under the control of the person relating to the safety or health of employees employed at the premises and, if any such records are not in the English or Chinese language, to produce a statement in writing in English or Chinese setting out the contents of those records;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: make copies of all or any part of any such records or statements.

subsection.content: An occupational safety officer who proposes to take a sample of a substance that is capable of being easily divided into parts must tell the occupier of the premises concerned or, if that occupier is not available, the person apparently in charge of those premises that that occupier or person is entitled to request the sample to be divided in accordance with subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: If such a request is made to an occupational safety officer, the officer must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: divide the sample into 3 more or less equal parts; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give one part of the sample to the person by whom or on whose behalf the request was made; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: submit another part to a public analyst for analysis; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: retain the third part for future comparison.

subsection.content: In legal proceedings arising under this Ordinance, a certificate, purporting to be signed by or with the authority of the public analyst by whom or under whose supervision a sample submitted for analysis under this section was analysed and stating the results of the analysis, is admissible in evidence in those proceedings.

A person who, for commercial purposes, uses the results of an analysis of a part of a sample submitted for analysis under this section commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 4. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 74)

subsection.leadIn: An occupational safety officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in order to make copies of records or statements produced in accordance with this section, take away and retain them for such period as may be reasonably necessary; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the officer reasonably believes that the records or statements are evidence of an offence against this Ordinance, take away and retain them until proceedings for the offence have been heard and finally determined.

subsection.content: Before taking away records or statements, an occupational safety officer must tender a receipt to the person from whose custody they are taken. The officer must give that person, or any person authorized by that person, access to the documents during the Labour Department’s ordinary hours of business.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Occupational safety officer may request certain information

subsection.leadIn: An occupational safety officer may request a person to provide—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: information that may identify the occupier of premises that the officer reasonably believes to be a workplace; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: information that may assist the officer to determine whether or not a contravention of this Ordinance is being or has been committed,

subsection.continued: but only if the officer reasonably believes that the person has that information and cannot reasonably obtain the information from another source.

subsection.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse, refuses to comply with a request made to the person under subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in response to such a request, provides information that the person knows or ought reasonably to know is false or misleading,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 75)

subsection.leadIn: A person does not have a reasonable excuse for refusing to comply with a request made under subsection (1) only because provision of the information might tend to incriminate the person. However, neither the request nor the information is admissible in criminal proceedings (other than proceedings charging the person with having committed in relation to the provision of the information an offence under subsection (2))—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if, before complying with the request, the person claims that the information provided might tend to incriminate the person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person’s entitlement to make such a claim was not brought to the person’s attention before the request was complied with.

subsection.content: The power conferred by this section may be exercised whether or not the occupational safety officer concerned is on premises entered in accordance with section 22.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Occupational safety officer may require responsible person to exhibit notice in workplace

subsection.leadIn: An occupational safety officer may require the person responsible for a workplace to exhibit at the workplace any specified notice relevant to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the operation of this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any plant or substance installed or kept at the workplace; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any commercial or industrial activity carried on at the workplace.

subsection.content: A requirement under this section must be in writing and may specify the period for which, and the manner and place in which, the relevant notice is to be exhibited.

If no such period is specified, the person responsible for the workplace must exhibit the notice for not less than 12 months. If no such place or manner is specified, that person must exhibit the notice conspicuously in a part of the workplace frequently visited by the employees concerned.

subsection.leadIn: A person responsible for a workplace who, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with a requirement made under this section; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: contravenes subsection (3),

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 76)

section.name: s26
section.heading: Offence to obstruct occupational safety officers and others exercising or performing functions under Ordinance

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without lawful excuse, resists, obstructs or delays an occupational safety officer who is exercising or performing or attempting to exercise or perform a function under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without lawful excuse, fails to comply with a requirement made to the person in accordance with section 23(1)(h) or (i); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: without lawful excuse, prevents, or attempts to prevent, another person from assisting an occupational safety officer in the exercise or performance of the officer’s functions under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: directly or indirectly, intimidates or threatens an occupational safety officer or person assisting such an officer in the exercise or performance of the officer’s functions under this Ordinance,

section.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Offence to impersonate occupational safety officer
section.content: A person who impersonates, or falsely represents that the person is, an occupational safety officer commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Public officers not personally liable for certain acts and omissions

subsection.content: A public officer, or a person assisting an occupational safety officer as provided by section 21(3)(a), is not personally liable for any act done or omitted to be done by the officer or person if the officer or person did or omitted to do the act in the honest belief that the act or omission was required or authorized by or under this Ordinance.
Subsection (1) does not affect any liability that the Government may have because a public officer or person has done or omitted to do an act to which that subsection applies.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Offence for public officers and others to disclose certain information

subsection.leadIn: A public officer commits an offence if, without lawful authority, the officer discloses to a person the name of, or any information that could identify, a person who has made a complaint—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: alleging a contravention of this Ordinance or the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as a result of which the officer or any other public officer has become aware of such a contravention.

subsection.leadIn: A public officer also commits an offence if, without lawful authority, the officer discloses—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the occupier of a workplace, or to an agent or employee of the occupier; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the employer of employees employed at a workplace is not the occupier of that place, to the employer, or to an agent or employee of the employer,

subsection.continued: that a visit to the workplace was made as a result of a complaint of a kind referred to in subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: A person who is or was formerly employed as a public officer commits an offence if, without lawful authority, the person discloses to another person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: information relating to manufacturing or commercial secrets or working processes that was obtained through the exercise or performance of a function under this Ordinance or the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: information notified by a medical practitioner in accordance with section 15.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section, a person has lawful authority to disclose information if the disclosure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is made in connection with the administration of this Ordinance (or the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59)); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is made for the purpose of complying with a requirement of another Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is ordered by a court, or by a person authorized by law to examine witnesses, in connection with the hearing or determination of any matter by the court or person.

subsection.content: A person who is convicted of an offence against this section is liable to a fine at level 4. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 79)

This section applies to a person who has accompanied or assisted an occupational safety officer as referred to in section 21(3)(a) or section 4(2A) of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59) as if the person were such an officer.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Offence for person to interfere with or misuse article provided for safety or health of employees
section.content: A person who intentionally or recklessly interferes with, or misuses, an article provided at a workplace in the interests of the safety or health of employees employed at the workplace commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Offence for employer to charge employees for anything done to fulfil statutory requirement

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: imposes or attempts to impose; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: authorizes the imposition of,

section.continued: a charge on any of the employer’s employees for anything done or provided under or for the purposes of this Ordinance commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Offence to prevent aid from being given to employee at workplace
section.content: A person who, by intimidation or by any other act or any omission, intentionally or recklessly prevents, obstructs or delays, without lawful authority or other reasonable excuse, the giving or receiving of aid in respect of an illness or injury of an employee at a workplace commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Liability of directors, partners, etc.

subsection.content: Where the person convicted of an offence against this Ordinance is a company and it is proved that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or was attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the company, the director, manager, secretary or other similar officer shall be guilty of the like offence.

Where the person convicted of an offence against this Ordinance is a firm and it is proved that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or was attributable to any neglect on the part of, any partner in the firm or any person concerned in the management of the firm, the partner or the person concerned in the management of the firm shall be guilty of the like offence.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Prosecution of offences

subsection.content: An occupational safety officer may, in the name of the Commissioner, bring and conduct a prosecution for any offence against this Ordinance, or an offence of conspiracy to commit such an offence. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 81)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (1), the offence must be tried before a magistrate as an offence that is triable summarily. (Added 5 of 2023 s. 81)

Subsection (1) applies despite section 12 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227), but nothing in this section limits the functions of the Secretary for Justice under that Ordinance with respect to the prosecution of offences. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

section.name: s34A
section.heading: Prosecution deadline
section.content: A prosecution for a summary offence under this Ordinance, or an indictable offence under this Ordinance that is to be tried summarily, may only be started before the end of 9 months beginning on the date on which the offence is committed.

statutoryNote.content: This replaces the time limit under section 26 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) in respect of a summary offence.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Not necessary to specify certain matters in summons for offence

subsection.content: A summons relating to an offence against this Ordinance may be addressed to the occupier of premises where a specified workplace is located without actually naming that occupier.

In a summons for an offence against this Ordinance alleging a failure to comply with a requirement or an obligation that has to be complied with only in so far as it is practicable or is reasonably practicable to do so, it is not necessary to aver that it was practicable, or was reasonably practicable, for the defendant to comply with the requirement or obligation.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Evidentiary statements

subsection.leadIn: In proceedings for an offence against this Ordinance, a statement, purporting to be signed by the Commissioner, is admissible in all legal proceedings as evidence of the matters contained in the statement if the statement—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a record kept by the Commissioner for the purposes of this Ordinance; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any other matter relating to occupational safety or health at work contained in an official document of a kind prescribed by a regulation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: certifies that the contents of the statement are in accordance with particulars contained in the record or document.

subsection.content: It is unnecessary to prove the signature of the Commissioner in a statement admissible under this section.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Evidence of employer-employee relationship
section.leadIn: Evidence that a person is engaged or employed in a particular economic activity that is, or was at a relevant time, carried on by another person, or was engaged or employed in a business or undertaking of which another person is the proprietor, is, for the purposes of any legal proceedings arising under this Ordinance, evidence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the person so engaged or employed is, or was at that time, an employee of the other person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the other person is, or was at that time, the employer of the person so engaged or employed.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Onus on defendant to prove certain matters
section.leadIn: In proceedings for an offence against this Ordinance involving a failure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to comply with a requirement or an obligation that has to be complied with only in so far as it is practicable or reasonably practicable to do so; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to take steps, reasonable steps or reasonably practicable steps to comply with the requirement or obligation,

section.continued: the onus is on the defendant to establish that compliance with the requirement or obligation was not practicable or was not reasonably practicable, or that steps, reasonable steps or reasonably practicable steps were taken to comply with the requirement or obligation.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Person not liable to be prosecuted twice for same act or omission
section.content: A person who has been convicted or acquitted of having committed an offence under a provision of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59) in relation to an act or omission is not liable to be proceeded against for an offence under a corresponding provision of this Ordinance relating to the same act or omission.

section.name: s39A
section.heading: Court to order convicted person to give financial information

subsection.content: The court must order a convicted person to give information on the turnover of the convicted person’s business to determine the scale of operation of the convicted person.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of complying with an order made under subsection (1), the convicted person must provide—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the return furnished by the convicted person for profits tax under section 51(1) of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a document containing the turnover information of the convicted person’s business that has been audited by a certified public accountant (practising) as defined by section 2(1) of the Accounting and Financial Reporting Council Ordinance (Cap. 588).

subsection.content: If the convicted person fails to comply with an order made under subsection (1) by giving sufficient information, the court may further order the convicted person to give any other financial information that the court considers relevant in determining the scale of operation of the convicted person.
Information given in compliance with an order made under subsection (1) or an order made under subsection (3), or both, must cover the year in which the offence is committed.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: convicted person (被定罪人士) means an employer, or an occupier of premises, who is convicted on indictment of an offence under this Ordinance;

turnover (營業額) means the revenue arising in or derived from Hong Kong from the principal business activities carried on in Hong Kong by a convicted person, but excluding the revenue that arises incidentally or is exceptional in nature;
year (年份), in relation to a convicted person, means—(a)the financial year of the convicted person; or(b)if the convicted person does not have a financial year, a calendar year.

section.name: s39B
section.heading: Court to take into account financial information of convicted person
section.leadIn: In determining the amount of the fine to be imposed on a convicted person (as defined by section 39A(5)), the court must take into account—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any financial information given by the convicted person (whether or not given in compliance with an order under section 39A(1) or (3)) that is relevant in determining the scale of operation of the convicted person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if no such information is given by the convicted person—any financial information from any other source provided by the prosecution that the court considers relevant in determining the scale of operation of the convicted person and reliable in the circumstances.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Workplace codes of practice

subsection.content: The Commissioner may issue codes of practice for the purpose of providing practical guidance to employers and employees, and to occupiers of workplaces who are not employers.

subsection.leadIn: A workplace code of practice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may consist of a code, standard, rule, specification or provision relating to occupational safety or health approved by the Commissioner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may apply, incorporate or refer to any document that has been formulated or published by a body or authority either as in force at the time when the document is approved by the Commissioner or as amended, formulated or published from time to time.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may amend or revoke a code of practice issued under this section.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner is required to publish in both English and Chinese—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any code of practice issued under this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the code is subsequently amended, the amendments made to the code.

subsection.continued: The publication may be in such form as the Commissioner considers will communicate the contents of the code or of the amendments to the people affected.

subsection.content: Whenever a code of practice is issued under this section or the code is amended or revoked, the Commissioner is required to publish in the Gazette a notice of the issue, amendment or revocation.

The Commissioner is required to make available at the head office of the Labour Department, during ordinary business hours, all workplace codes of practice for inspection by members of the public. No charge is to be made for the inspection of a workplace code of practice.
A workplace code of practice takes effect on the date on which notice of the code is published in the Gazette or on such later date as is specified in the notice.
An amendment to a workplace code of practice takes effect on the date on which notice of the amendment is published in the Gazette or on such later date as is specified in the notice.
A workplace code of practice ceases to have effect on the date on which notice of revocation of the code is published in the Gazette or on such later date as is specified in the notice.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Effect of workplace code of practice

subsection.content: A person does not incur a civil or criminal liability only because the person has contravened a provision of a workplace code of practice.

subsection.leadIn: However, if, in any legal proceedings the court is satisfied that a workplace code of practice is relevant to determining a matter that is in issue in the proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the code of practice is admissible in evidence in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proof that the person contravened or did not contravene a relevant provision of the code may be relied on by any party to the proceedings as tending to establish or negate that matter.

subsection.content: In any legal proceedings, a document that purports to be a copy of a workplace code of practice is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to be presumed to be a true copy of the code.
A workplace code of practice is not subsidiary legislation for the purposes of Part V of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1).

section.name: s42
section.heading: Commissioner may make regulations

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may make regulations for or with respect to all or any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensuring the safety and health of employees when they are at work;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: imposing additional responsibilities on employers and employees and on occupiers of workplaces who are not employers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: prescribing anything required or permitted to be prescribed by a regulation;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: generally, providing for the better carrying into effect of the provisions and purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In particular, the Commissioner may make regulations for or with respect to all or any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensuring the provision at workplaces of adequate facilities for treating bodily injuries to employees as a result of accidents occurring at those workplaces;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing for the removal from, and the avoidance at, workplaces of dangers and potential dangers to employees at those workplaces;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: prescribing precautions to be taken to prevent outbreaks of fire at workplaces and to protect employees employed at those workplaces from the consequences of outbreaks of fire there (including provision of adequate means of escape);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: ensuring that workplaces are maintained in a hygienic condition;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: prohibiting persons, or persons of a specified class, from being employed to undertake any specified kind of activity at a workplace or regulating the carrying on of an activity of that kind at a workplace;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: prohibiting persons who are responsible for workplaces from operating or using any specified kind of plant at those workplaces, or regulating the operation or use of any such plant;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: prohibiting persons who are responsible for workplaces from storing or using any specified kind of substance at those workplaces, or regulating the storage or use of any substance of that kind;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: providing for the medical examination of employees employed at workplaces and for the keeping of records of those examinations;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: requiring persons who are responsible for workplaces to notify particulars of those workplaces to the Commissioner and, where those particulars change, to notify the Commissioner of the changes;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: providing for activities undertaken at workplaces to be assessed in order to determine the extent of risk of those activities to the safety or health of employees employed at those workplaces;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: requiring persons who are responsible for workplaces to keep records of specified activities carried on at those workplaces;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: requiring persons, in any circumstances arising out of the risk of absorbing any substance at a workplace or the risk of bodily injury arising out of the use of any substance at a workplace, to undergo a specified biochemical or biological test;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: prescribing measures for detecting and investigating cases in which absorption of any substance, or bodily injury arising out of the use of any substance, has occurred (including medical examinations, the carrying out of biochemical or biological tests and notification of absences of employees from work);

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: conferring rights of appeal from specified kinds of decisions of the Commissioner or an occupational safety officer under this Ordinance and providing for the hearing and determination of those appeals;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: prescribing information that occupational safety officers are required to provide to employers or other persons in specified circumstances;

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: providing for the forms to be used for the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.content: All regulations made by the Commissioner shall be subject to the approval of the Legislative Council.

A regulation may apply, adopt or incorporate by reference, with or without modification, any publication (including any Ordinance or subsidiary legislation), either as in force at the time of publication or as in force from time to time.

subsection.leadIn: A regulation may make it an offence for a person to do or omit to do any specified act and may authorize—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the imposition of a fine, not exceeding $400,000, for such an offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the offence is a continuing one, the imposition of a further fine of $10,000 for each day or part of a day during which the offence has continued. (Amended 5 of 2023 s. 85)

subsection.content: A regulation may declare any particular offence created under subsection (5) to be an offence of strict liability.

A regulation that creates an offence that is not one of strict liability may, in addition to or instead of a fine, authorize the imposition of a sentence of imprisonment for a period of not more than 12 months, but only if, in the case of proceedings for such an offence, it is proved that the defendant committed the offence intentionally or recklessly or with knowledge of all of the ingredients of the offence.

subsection.leadIn: A regulation may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: apply generally or be limited in its application by reference to specified exceptions or factors; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply differently according to different factors of a specified kind; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: authorize any matter or thing to be determined, applied or regulated by any specified person or group of persons,

subsection.continued: or may do any combination of those things.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Commissioner may amend Schedules
section.content: The Commissioner may, by order published in the Gazette, amend Schedule 1 or 2 by adding a new item or by replacing or altering an existing item, but only if the amendment promotes the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Commissioner may grant exemptions from operation of Ordinance

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, by notice in writing, exempt a person from the operation of a specified requirement of this Ordinance if the Commissioner is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is not reasonably practicable for the person to comply with the requirement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: having regard to the relevant circumstances, it is reasonable that the person should be exempted from the requirement.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may, in granting such an exemption, impose conditions on the exempted person.

An exemption granted under this section ceases to have effect if any condition imposed under this section on the exempted person is contravened. In that event this Ordinance applies to the person as if the exemption had not been granted.
The power conferred by this section must be exercised by the Commissioner personally or by a public officer specifically designated by the Commissioner for the purpose.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner must keep a register of exemptions and ensure that every exemption granted in accordance with this section is recorded in the register. The Commissioner must also ensure that the register—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is kept at the head office of the Labour Department; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is made available for inspection by members of the public without charge during the ordinary business hours of that office.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may at any time, by notice in writing served on the exempted person, revoke an exemption granted under this section or vary any condition to which such an exemption is subject.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Requirements imposed by Ordinance on 2 or more different persons

subsection.content: A requirement imposed by or under this Ordinance on 2 or more different persons is taken to have been complied with by each of those persons if any one of them has fully complied with the requirement.
This section is subject to any express provision of this Ordinance to the contrary.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Regulations and codes of practice under Ordinance to prevail

subsection.content: A provision of a regulation made under this Ordinance is to prevail over any inconsistent provision of a regulation made under the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59).

A provision of a code of practice issued under this Ordinance is to prevail over any inconsistent provision of a code of practice issued under the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59).

section.name: s47
section.heading: How documents are to be served for purposes of Ordinance
section.leadIn: A document to be served for the purposes of this Ordinance may be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a person other than a body corporate or partnership—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by delivering it to the person personally; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by sending it by registered post in a letter addressed to the person at the person’s usual place of residence or business or, if the person’s address is unknown, addressed to the person’s last known place of residence or business; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a body corporate—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by delivering it to any place in Hong Kong at which the body carries on business and giving it to a person apparently concerned in the management of, or apparently employed by, the body; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by sending it to the body by registered post by letter addressed to the body at its registered office in Hong Kong or at any place in Hong Kong at which the body carries on business; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a partnership—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: by delivering it to any place in Hong Kong at which the partnership carries on business and giving it to a person apparently concerned in the management of, or apparently employed by, the partnership; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: by sending it to the partnership by registered post by letter addressed to the partnership at any place in Hong Kong at which the partnership carries on business.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Savings and transitional provisions
section.content: Schedule 5 (containing savings and transitional provisions) has effect.

section.name: s1
section.content: The disintegration of a revolving vessel, wheel, grindstone or grinding wheel that is operated by mechanical power.

section.name: s2
section.content: The collapse or failure of a lifting appliance (except the breakage of chain or rope slings).

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: causes damage to the structure of any workplace, or to any plant or substance at a workplace; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prevents the continuation of ordinary work at the workplace.

section.name: s4
section.leadIn: An electrical short circuit or electrical failure of electrical plant that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is followed by, or associated with, an explosion or fire; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: causes structural damage to the plant,

section.continued: being a short circuit, failure, explosion, fire or damage that stops the operation of the plant or prevents it from being used.

section.name: s5
section.content: An explosion of a receiver or container used for the storage at a pressure greater than atmospheric pressure or of any gas or gases (including air) or any liquid or solid resulting from the compression of gases.

section.content: A total or partial collapse of a roof, wall, floor, structure or foundation of premises where a workplace is located.

section.name: s7
section.content: A total or partial collapse of any overburden, face, tip or embankment within a quarry.

paragraph.name: a

section.name: s1
section.heading: Chief Executive may make savings and transitional regulation

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may make regulations, subject to the approval of the Legislative Council, containing provisions of a savings or transitional nature consequent on the enactment of this Ordinance. (Amended 54 of 2000 s. 3)
A provision referred to in subsection (1) may, if the regulation so provides, take effect from the date of assent to this Ordinance or a later date.

subsection.leadIn: To the extent to which a provision referred to in subsection (1) takes effect from a date that is earlier than the date of its publication in the Gazette, the provision does not operate so as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to affect, in a manner prejudicial to any person (other than the Government or a public body), the rights of that person existing before the date of its publication; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to impose liabilities on any person (other than the Government or a public body) in respect of anything done, or omitted to be done, before the date of its publication.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Inquiries under Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance
section.content: Despite the repeal of sections 11A and 11B of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59), an inquiry pending under either of those sections immediately before their repeal may be continued and completed as if those sections had not been repealed.
